text: Situation A. Strategies from Ms. Ramiro's Class
The following are student suggestions for estimating the population based on random samples. Do these comparisons make sense? Explain why or why not.

As a measure of center, the median gives an indication of the number that might be expected in a sample of 10 chips. It can be used to predict the population.

Mateo’s group matches the population by scaling up their median data.

Scaling a proportion from a sample is a way to predict a population. However, not all samples will mirror a population. This is an example of the sample not being large enough, not being random, or just not mirroring the population. In this case, the sample of red chips did not mirror the population. Including all 10 samples will help with the variability.

This can happen with just one sample. It illustrates why we sometimes take more than one sample.
A container contains 100 chips with an unknown number or blue, orange, and yellow chips. A box plot and bar graph with the number of blue chips from 36 samples of 10 chips are shown. The median is 4.

1. What do you notice about the distribution of blue chips in the graphs?
  2. If we sample the mystery container 100 times, how many blue chips would you expect in each of the samples?

1. Answers will vary.

Example answer:

The data are almost symmetrical. It grows to 4 chips then decreases. It seems to cluster around 3 - 4 chips. The box plot shows 50% of the data are 3 - 4 chips.

The range of the cubes is 6.

4 cubes is the mode and median. The mean is 3.4 cubes.

Note: In this case, the median and Q3 are the same values.

In general to analyze a numerical data distribution, students might look for

- SHAPE such as

clusters (where groups of data bunch together),

gaps (where there isn’t any data);

- SPREAD such as

range (the difference between the smallest and largest data pieces),

IQR (the spread of between the third and first quartiles – the center 50% of the data values)

MAD (the spread of the data values away from the mean); and

- MEASURES OF CENTER such as

mode (the data that occurs the most frequently),

median (the middle data piece when data is listed in order from smallest to largest),

mean (the “summing” and “sharing” of the values among the total number of observations).

2. From 3 to 4 blue chips in samples of 10.
